page.title: 13LANGUAGE
page.content: Apart from the USAF Base at Woodbridge with its ethnic mix of nationalities, the basic dialect in this area is cha- racterised by a narrowness and tenuity of pronunciation, being the reverse of the round sonorious northern English. Little could be found on the meanings of place-names. Some interesting words and phrases peculiar to this area are: Borh: (familiar address): boy; Maukin: scarecrow; Shanny: scatter-brain; Dag: dew or misty rain; Hawkey: harvest- feast; Mauther: girl; Wet bir (pron. 'bu'): woodpecker (heralds rain when heard tapping); Chaits: left-overs; Bumby: toilet; Gansey: jersey; Loaded down to the eccelstree: fully loaded (as a cart); He's a lim for fry and a rat for cheese: a glutton for punish- ment. A grut ol' rallux: tall and lanky; A long Melford: a long purse; Harnsey or Hansa: heron.
